Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 Integer Programming and Combinatorial Optimization (IPCO)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2019 Conference on Integer Programming and Combinatorial Optimization(IPCO) and the associated IPCO Summer School runs annually under the auspices of the Mathematical Optimization Society, the leading organization for research in mathematical optimization. IPCO presents the latest ground-breaking results aimed at the solution of difficult decision and optimization problems that have strong ramifications throughout engineering, logistics, mathematics and science. It is a competitive refereed conference. This award supports student travel, attendance and participation, including by members of under-represented groups. Supporting students in this fashion is vital for the long-term success of the combinatorial-optimization community.

IPCO 2019 will be held at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Michigan, May 22-24, 2019. The IPCO Summer School, aimed at graduate students, will be at the University of Michigan, May 20-21, 2019. The subject of the IPCO Summer School are: Discrepancy and Combinatorial Optimization, Semidefinite Programming for Combinatorial Optimization, and Sums of Squares in Polynomial Optimization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award was for student support to attend the 20th Conference on Integer Programming and Combinatorial Optimization (IPCO) and the associated summer school. The IPCO 2019 conference and summer school were held May 20-24, 2019, at Ann Arbor, MI, USA. Integer programming and combinatorial optimization are topics that relate to the optimal use of resources in constrained environments. These are key topics within operations research, logictics, and analytics. IPCO is the premier conference on nteger programming and combinatorial optimization. 

The summer school was on semidefinite and polynomial optimization. There were three invited speakers: Nikhil Bansal (T.U. Eindhoven) spoke on “Discrepancy and Combinatorial Optimization”, Samuel Burer (U. Iowa) spoke on “Semidefinite Programming for Combinatorial Optimization” and Joao Gouveia (U. Coimbra) spoke on “Sums of Squares in Polynomial Optimization”. Each speaker presented two lecture sessions (2.5 hours) and one problem session (1 hour). The presentations were spread over two days (May 20-21, 2019). All the material from the summer school are available online at:

http://umich.edu/~ipco2019conf/summerschool.html

The main IPCO conference was held May 22-24, 2019. It featured 33 talks on the papers accepted to the conference. There was also a poster session, where some of the summer school attendees presented their recent work.
